unnormalised: I saw someone asking about how much Indians usually spend on groceries per month, so thought I'd share my experience and maybe others can chime in too. It really depends on a bunch of factors, ya know? Like, where you live, how many people you're feeding, and your lifestyle.
normalised: I saw someone asking about how much Indians usually spend on groceries per month, so thought I would share my experience and maybe others can chime in too. It really depends on a bunch of factors, you know? Like, where you live, how many people you are feeding, and your lifestyle.

unnormalised: Firstly, city matters a lot. Groceries in Mumbai are definitely pricier than in, say, a smaller town in Uttar Pradesh. My cousin in Lucknow tells me he spends around Rs. 4000 per month for his family of four. Whereas, in Bangalore, for a similar family size, you might be looking at Rs. 6000-Rs. 8000. Rent alone can add so much.
normalised: Firstly, city matters a lot. Groceries in Mumbai are definitely pricier than in, say, a smaller town in Uttar Pradesh. My cousin in Lucknow tells me he spends around rupee four thousand per month for his family of four. Whereas, in Bangalore, for a similar family size, you might be looking at rupee six thousand to rupee eight thousand. Rent alone can add so much.

unnormalised: Then, there's the vegetarian vs. non-vegetarian thing. Veggies generally cost less, but if you're a meat-eater, especially if you prefer chicken or mutton daily, budget can easily shoot up. Fish, too, especially in coastal areas, can be expensive depending on the type – maybe Rs. 300/kg for pomfret or something.
normalised: Then, there is the vegetarian versus non-vegetarian thing. Veggies generally cost less, but if you are a meat-eater, especially if you prefer chicken or mutton daily, budget can easily shoot up. Fish, too, especially in coastal areas, can be expensive depending on the type – maybe rupee three hundred per kilogram for pomfret or something.

unnormalised: Also, consider whether you buy from local markets or supermarkets. Supermarkets like D-Mart or Reliance Fresh are convenient but sometimes pricier compared to the sabzi mandi, where you can bargain. I sometimes get lucky buying from local vendors in the evening after 8 pm. They try to get rid of the stuff that would otherwise go bad, for cheap.
normalised: Also, consider whether you buy from local markets or supermarkets. Supermarkets like D-Mart or Reliance Fresh are convenient but sometimes pricier compared to the sabzi mandi, where you can bargain. I sometimes get lucky buying from local vendors in the evening after eight P.M. They try to get rid of the stuff that would otherwise go bad, for cheap.

unnormalised: What about organic? If you're into organic produce, be prepared to shell out more. Organic veggies and fruits can cost 2x or even 3x the regular price. My neighbour swears by it and spends easily ₹10000+ on groceries.
normalised: What about organic? If you are into organic produce, be prepared to shell out more. Organic veggies and fruits can cost two x or even three x the regular price. My neighbor swears by it and spends easily rupee ten thousand plus on groceries.

unnormalised: My own family of three in Delhi spends around Rs. 7000. That covers basic dals, rice, vegetables, milk (1 liter daily), and some fruits. We try to eat simple meals most of the time. Occasionally we might buy some meat from a local shop.
normalised: My own family of three in Delhi spends around rupee seven thousand. That covers basic dals, rice, vegetables, milk (one liter daily), and some fruits. We try to eat simple meals most of the time. Occasionally we might buy some meat from a local shop.

unnormalised: Finally, consider online shopping. Grofers/Blinkit can be handy but keep an eye on delivery charges and deals. Sometimes they have flash sales where you can snag some good discounts. Usually, I have about 1000-2000 Rs. worth of savings on each online purchase. I got 5 kilos of rice for just Rs. 250 a while ago!
normalised: Finally, consider online shopping. Grofers slash Blinkit can be handy but keep an eye on delivery charges and deals. Sometimes they have flash sales where you can snag some good discounts. Usually, I have about one thousand to two thousand rupees worth of savings on each online purchase. I got five kilos of rice for just rupee two hundred and fifty a while ago!

unnormalised: So, yeah, it's a complex question with no one-size-fits-all answer. But I hope this gives you some idea! Share your experiences, folks! What's your grocery budget?
